    • adaptiveSamplingRecursion

      public Color adaptiveSamplingRecursion​(int nx, int ny, double distance, double width, double height, Render.Pixel pixel, int level, double reduce, Point3D center)
      recursive function that calculates the color of each pixel with adaptive super sampling
      Parameters:
      nx - amount of pixels on X
      ny - amount of pixels on y
      distance - screen distance from camera
      width - screen width
      height - screen height
      pixel - pixel
      level - recursive level
      reduce - reduce the pixel into a sub pixel
      center - center of sub pixel
      Returns:
      Color of a pixel

    • renderImage

      public void renderImage()
      Filling the buffer according to the geometries that are in the scene. This function is not creating the picture file, but create the buffer pf pixels

    • calcSpecular

      private Color calcSpecular​(double ks, Vector l, Vector n, double nl, Vector v, int nShininess, Color ip)
      Calculate Specular component of light reflection.
      Parameters:
      ks - specular component coef
      l - direction from light to point
      n - normal to surface at the point
      nl - dot-product n*l
      v - direction from point of view to point
      nShininess - shininess level
      ip - light intensity at the point
      Returns:
      specular component light effect at the point

      Finally, the Phong model has a provision for a highlight, or specular, component, which reflects light in a shiny way. This is defined by [rs,gs,bs](-V.R)^p, where R is the mirror reflection direction vector we discussed in class (and also used for ray tracing), and where p is a specular power. The higher the value of p, the shinier the surface.

    • calcDiffusive

      private Color calcDiffusive​(double kd, double nl, Color ip)
      Calculate Diffusive component of light reflection.
      Parameters:
      kd - diffusive component coef
      nl - dot-product n*l
      ip - light intensity at the point
      Returns:
      diffusive component of light reflection

      The diffuse component is that dot product nâ€¢L that we discussed in class. It approximates light, originally from light source L, reflecting from a surface which is diffuse, or non-glossy. One example of a non-glossy surface is paper. In general, you'll also want this to have a non-gray color value, so this term would in general be a color defined as: [rd,gd,bd](nâ€¢L)
